p:
Before closing this section, we employed the finite-difference scheme (3.2) to confirm the validity of the analytical results. Fig. 3 shows the solution of the system (2.1) using the method proposed in this work. To that end, we employed the parameters of Table 1, and the initial conditions are. Two cases were considered, namely, (a) a system free of COVID-19 and (b) a system with the presence of COVID-19. The graphs show that the solutions tend to the prescribed equilibrium points C 1 and C 2, respectively. It is worth pointing out that these results are in full agreement with both the analytical and the numerical theorems derived in this work. Fig. 3(c) shows the the dynamics of the model (2.1) when it transits from COVID-19 present to COVID-19 absent with
q 1
= 0.014
. Meanwhile, Fig. 3(c) shows the effect of the quarantine parameter on infected humans. As expected, increasing q 1 reduces the number of infected individuals. In the simulations, we used
S 0
= 0.5 ,
E 0
= 0.2 ,
I 0
= 0.1 ,
Q 0
= 0.1 ,
R 0
= 0.1
and
τ = 0.01
.
